title: What's the most British thing about America? Anything distinct held over from the heritage as a Crown Colony? - Quora
tags: History of the United States of America

response.answer_text: British things about the USA? Here’s the beginning of a list. Language, common law, bicameral parliament, court of appeal, citizenship by birthright, the volume of legal precedent that predates 1776, units of measurement like the inch, mile, pound, ounce, cup and dozen. Separation of judicial, legislative and executive powers. Municipal government. The Episcopalian, Congregationalist, Methodist, Presbyterian and other churches. Acceptance of Jews and Roman Catholics and the idea of religious toleration. The concept of British/Anglo-Israelism. Both slavery and emancipation. The Federal Reserve was modeled after the Bank of England. Adam Smith and the idea of using capitalism to build a nation was Scottish. The concept of limiting the power of the state by constitution. Malting and fermentation of grain, distilled grain spirits (whisky!). The idea of a University as an establishment of higher learning. Horses and their use. Industrialization, using tools like steam engines, factories and railways. The concept of a common or area jointly owned by all. The concept of Manifest Destiny - empire for the Brits, the Americas for the USA. The desire for empire and conquest to “civilize” other nations, like the Philippines, Guam, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, USVI and Alaska. That’s just a start of the list of ideas and institutions the USA took from their British past. There are many more items, if you stop and think. The US isn’t so different from the UK in many ways. In others? They’re oceans apart!

Racism. Cultural Supremacy, exemplified in instances of colonization by imperial propaganda. The best thing that i personally portray to you on this subject, is that of the names of some of your cities and towns which have come from locations here in England. I refer to the namesake locations for both the UK and the USA…. examples such as : Portland Dorset / Portland Oregon Boston Lincolnshire / Boston Mass Plymouth Devon / Plymouth Mass Exeter Devon / Exeter California Wellington Somerset / Wellington Colorado Winchester Hampshire / Winchester Georgia The list is huge !!

Not much, we fought a huge and bloody war to get away from British rule. We’ve pretty much distanced ourselves from them since. Now Canada and Australia might have kept some traditions but I’m not sure about that. Besides most of the European heritage in the US is German so we’ve kept more German traditions than British. Such as having a Christmas tree. But even the German traditions aren’t a lot, most Protestant Germans came here to flee the horrors the Catholic church. During WW1 a lot of German Americans distanced themselves from their heritage because of discrimination, most changing the sound of their last names or changing it completely to sound more “American” Now, the European descendants in America are mixed so there aren’t many of us who are 100% any European country anymore.

Not really a British thing, almost a contrast with being British, but their incredible fascination with British Royalty as if they were from Hollywood. A Number of countries have Royalty, why not pursue them instead. or just your own “Royalty” those with the most material posessions.
Language, common law, bicameral parliament, court of appeal, citizenship by birthright, the volume of legal precedent that predates 1776, etc.
Our principal language is English. That, and our system of Common Law, are just about the ONLY things left that we inherited from England.
Can’t think of anything off-hand other than American English. The USA surpassed the UK one hundred years ago.
As an aside, you need to be careful of the use of the phrase “Crown Colony”, many of the colonies were not sponsored by the crown, but were private ventures.
The Language is probably the prime aspects of legacy. Religion, Rule of Law, Its’ Universities…they pre-date the Revolution.
